questions.question_text: Which of the following commands will NOT update the modify timestamp on the file /tmp/myfile.txt?

discussion.content: The file command is used to determine the type of a file and it does not modify the contents of the file. As a result, the modify timestamp of the file /tmp/myfile.txt would not be updated when the file command is executed.
he default nice level when a process is started using the nice command is 0.

questions.question_text: What is the default nice level when a process is started using the nice command?
What is the default action of the split command on an input file?

choices.C: It will break the file into new files of 1,024 kilobyte pieces each.
choices.B: It will break the file into new files of 1,000 line pieces each.
choices.D: It will break the file into new files that are no more than 5% of the size of the original file.
choices.A: It will break the file into new files of 1,024 byte pieces each.

discussion.content: The default action of the split command on an input file is to break the file into new files of 1,000 line pieces each.

questions.question_text: In Bash, inserting 1>&2 after a command redirects

discussion.content:
n Bash, inserting 1>&2 after a command redirects standard output to standard error.

The number 1 refers to the file descriptor for standard output (stdout), and the &2 refers to the file descriptor for standard error (stderr). The > operator is used to redirect output from one file descriptor to another.

So, when you run a command followed by 1>&2, the standard output of that command will be redirected to standard error, which means that the output of the command will be written to the same place as error messages. This can be useful in certain situations, such as when you want to capture both the output and error messages of a command in the same log file.

questions.question_text: What is the effect of the egrep command when the -v option is used?

choices.A: It enables color to highlight matching parts.
choices.C: It shows the command's version information.
choices.D: It changes the output order showing the last matching line first.

discussion.content:
The effect of the egrep command when the -v option is used is option B: it only outputs non-matching lines. The -v option inverts the match, so instead of showing lines that match a pattern, it shows lines that do not match the pattern.

egrep is a command-line tool that is used to search for text patterns in files or streams of text. It stands for "extended grep" and is similar to the grep command, but with more advanced pattern matching capabilities.

egrep uses regular expressions to match patterns in the text, and it can search for patterns that include special characters, such as metacharacters and quantifiers. These allow for more complex and flexible pattern matching.
